oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One-page printed and handwritten Board of Trade affidavit represents the oath of R. G. Page that the dry goods supplies that he requires for his retail business in Nashville will be used for approved purposes and that he is a loyal citizen. The attached handwritten memorandum from Page states that the requested supplies will be shipped from Cincinnati and that their value is $9,000.00. President of the Board of Trade Edward H. East signed the affidavit.

oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Record Group 21, Adjutant General's Office Records, 1796-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nashville's Board of Trade was established by Miltary Governor Andrew Johnson, in conjunction with the U. S. Treasury Department, following Federal occupation of the city during the Civil War. The Board was Johnson's effort to regulate commerce with the manufacturers and merchants. Both the offices of the Federal Quartermaster and Tennessee's Adjutant General were involved in this endeavor, as this was actually a military board of trade.
